utterances: And I'm Audie Cornish.
On the op-ed page of The New York Times today, the actress Angelina Jolie revealed she recently had a preventive double mastectomy, both breasts removed and then reconstructed.
Her mother died of breast cancer at 56 and Jolie herself had been diagnosed with the inherited BRCA1 gene mutation, which significantly increases the risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
And so, she writes: I decided to be proactive and to minimize the risk as much as I could.
Of course, there are women everywhere who carry the same gene mutation as Angelina Jolie.
But do they have the same sort of access to genetic counseling and medical procedures?
To help answer that, we're joined by Sue Friedman.
She's founder and executive director of the group FORCE.
That stands for Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered.
Sue Friedman, welcome.
Thank you for having me.
So, first, to be clear, the majority of breast cancers are not caused by a BRCA gene mutation.
But if you do have the mutation, you're much more likely to develop breast or ovarian cancer, is that correct?
That's correct.
About five to seven percent of breast cancer, about 14 to 20 percent of ovarian cancer is due to a gene mutation - so, not the majority.
And people who inherit a BRCA mutation are at very high risk for both cancers and also at somewhat higher risk for other cancers, too.

Now, Angelina Jolie writes in this New York Times op-ed that: Today, it is possible to find out through a blood test whether you are highly susceptible to breast and ovarian cancer and then take action.
But how easy is it for women to do so?
And, for instance, do most insurance policies cover the steps that she took?
So, there are national guidelines that determine who should and who will get the most benefit from a genetic evaluation.

It's important to us to make sure people know that you should see an expert known as a genetic counselor, or a medical geneticist, in order to find out what your risk is, rather than just going out and getting a blood test.
And if the chance of having a mutation is high enough, based on expert guidelines, most insurances will cover genetic counseling and genetic testing.
But what about that next course of action?
In this case, Angelina Jolie talked about a preventive double mastectomy.
Is that something covered?
What are the out-of-pocket costs involved here?
A lot of it depends - there's a lot of different options for the types of mastectomy and reconstruction.
It's actually - that technology has come a long way, and it depends on people's insurances.
But we have found in the FORCE community, which is thousands of women who have undergone these procedures, most insurances will pay for mastectomy.
And if they pay for mastectomy, they must also pay for reconstruction based on federal law that was passed in 1998.
Now, Angelina Jolie also said that she started with the mastectomies because her risk of breast cancer was higher than her risk of ovarian cancer and that the surgery is more complex.
Now, does your organization, FORCE, advocate for one course of action over another?
So the grasshopper mice are underground in the prairie dog towns just passing through.
These fleas are killing a family of prairie dogs.
They need blood; they jump on the mice.
Unidentified Man #4: Qatar or Qatar.
So just to note a couple things you said, you talk about the bond notes, which are kind of government IOUs because there is so little currency in circulation.
So you're sitting here, wearing the Zimbabwean flag, which is what you spoke about in the viral video that started this whole campaign.
And you've been traveling around the United States.
But why are you here?
Are you here to inform people?
Are you seeking asylum?
Are you planning to stay?
Yes, I've taken some time out and away from Zimbabwe, and rightfully so because of the situation that now began to surround my presence in Zimbabwe.
The president himself personally has threatened me on many occasions in his speeches, and in one of the speeches literally said that there is no place for someone like me in a nation like Zimbabwe.
So it is to be responsible enough to put my family in a safe space.
Can you say with any certainty whether you will return to Zimbabwe and when?
I'm not permanently going to be here.
Zimbabwe is my home.
Whilst I may not be able to say when exactly, I can definitely let you know that I will be going back to Zimbabwe.
Tell us the story of your arrest in July and the circumstances around your release.

What we had done is that we had encouraged people not to go to work on the 6th of June as a way of registering discontent with the mismanagement of the country, particularly with corruption, injustice and poverty.
So the shutdown of the country was a huge success.
Nobody went to work.
The whole country came to a standstill from top to bottom.
And so the police decided that they would question me because some violence had taken place in other parts of the country.

And eventually, they came up with a charge against me of inciting public violence, even though in my social media videos I had always and continue even up to now to advocate for non-violence in our protest.
And then the next day I had to go and appear before the magistrate.
My lawyer, who was there, also informed me that about a hundred other lawyers had showed up at the court to come and defend me.
And right there is when I started to have a sense that something really amazing was taking place not just for me, but for many Zimbabweans who were now taking the issue of injustice very personally.

Eventually, my lawyer, together with the help of these many lawyers, were able to present a case that it was a violation of my constitutional rights as a citizen and the magistrate had no choice but to release me.
And on coming out of the court - it was incredible, Farai - I saw thousands of people that had come to the courthouse.
They had flags.
They were singing.
They were chanting.
They were praying on their knees.
And this is in front of a riot police who are very brutal in Zimbabwe.
But some of these same supporters who came out for you physically or followed the movement through social media are now saying that you've abandoned them.
How do you respond to people who are - who feel betrayed?
There's a sense that I totally understand where you are coming from in that the feeling was that we had a flicker of hope that we had hoped we would ignite into a bonfire.
We have not lost that.
The fact of the matter is that the change for Zimbabwe was never going to be housed in one person.
It was always going to be a united front of people, everybody putting their hands on deck in the same way that people did when they came to the court.
They didn't come to the court for me.
They came to the court for Zimbabwe.

But a little bit about what has happened around me during that time that a lot of people don't understand - at about 1 a.m. whilst we were in the cell, a man came to interrogate me and asked me to come into a room with him.
He says, you tell me right now you're sitting in this cell.
If somebody was to show up at your house and rape your wife, how would you defend her?
How would you tell anyone?
Your lawyer doesn't even know that you're sitting with me in this room right now.
In fact, if you go back into the cell where you've come from, you could very well get raped yourself there and never be able to prove that it actually happened to you.
And, of course, that was a way of threatening, but it made me think deeply about the fact that we don't have to always put ourselves in mortal danger to bring about the change we want.
I think that there are ways that we can continue to fight and continue to put pressure.
And so I stand by my decision.

And my hope is that whether or not I am a betrayal or whether or not my cause was real in the eyes of Zimbabweans, the fact that remains is that we have a government on our hands that must be held to account, and we cannot abandon that.
That's Pastor Evan Mawarire.
He's the founder of This Flag campaign in Zimbabwe, and he joined us in our studios in D.C.
Thank you, pastor.
Thank you so much for having me, Farai.
Good morning, I'm Ari Shapiro.
Wal-Mart is trying to change its cold corporate image, literally.
Workers complain of freezing on the job.
Yesterday, Wal-Mart executives told thousands of employees that the stores will be warmer.
Workers also complained that they are bombarded by a constant assault from Celine Dion and Justin Bieber songs over the in-store soundtrack.
Now a human DJ will pick the music, and that's good news for shoppers, too.
It's MORNING EDITION.
Let's get a French journalist's perspective on yesterday's shooting in Paris.
The target was the magazine Charlie Hebdo.
One of the news organizations covering the story is Le Monde, where Sylvie Kauffman is editorial director.
Welcome to the program.
Hello.
Good morning.
How have your colleagues in France's news media been responding to this?

Well, obviously this has been a tremendous shock for everybody, for the public at large, certainly, and particularly for the journalists because Charlie Hebdo was not - is not just any other magazine.
It's a very special magazine to the French.
It's a satirical magazine.
And it's really read across the board in France by people who can be on the left, on the right wing of the political spectrum - I mean, from working class, from intellectuals, from the establishment.
It's a traditional irreverence and wit.
It's very French, in a way.
So striking at Charlie Hebdo, we have this feeling that it's also striking at the heart of the French national identity.
And also...
You're making a valuable point here because I think Americans get the impression that this might have been almost a marginal magazine because its attacks were so strong.
But you're saying they mocked everyone, and they were enjoyed by all kinds of people.
Is another round of stimulus even conceivable on Capitol Hill?
Well, I mean, if it was such a - you know, we spent how many trillions of dollars in debt?
Yeah, well, we actually just got back to our hotel after sitting in gridlock traffic for over an hour.
Everyone is rushing to the markets and the stores to stock up on foods, to get ready for these three days when they're not going to be allowed to leave their houses.
But in the sort of bustling heart of the city - we went down to a market, an open-air market.
That was absolutely jam-packed, people everywhere.
And I spoke with a woman named Miriam Kalom (ph) who told me she was really upset that this lockdown was leading to pretty severe price inflation.
Everything is so expensive
It's, like, a lot more expensive than usual.
Yes, everything expensive today, then double, double, double the price.
And she was also concerned that with all these people in the market, where they're sweating and packed closely together, that Ebola might actually be spread around there.
And she was scared to go in and buy the food that she needed for the next few days.
So to her, it felt like this whole lockdown strategy might even be making the situation worse.
Her fears are obviously real.
Are they, in fact, justified?
Can one contract Ebola that way?
It's very unlikely that she would contract Ebola that way.
But I think the lesson here is that this lockdown is creating even more confusion.
People are told not to go into crowded areas, not to have physical contact with other people.
And yet, here in this crowded market, that's exactly what was happening.
Anders, thank you.
Thanks, Robert.
It's MORNING EDITION, from NPR News.
Good morning.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm David Greene.
A week ago, everyone seemed to be talking about the Maya people of Mexico and Central America.
Due to a misinterpretation of the Mayan calendar, word spread that the ancient culture had predicted the end of the world on December 21st.
